questions.text: A 55-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with fever with chills, diarrhea and new onset cardiac murmur. Candida species are isolated from her blood culture and IV fluconazole is considered for treatment. Which of the following Candida species is least likely to respond to azole therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Candida krusei

Explanation:

Candida krusei is resistant to azole antifungals, especially fluconazole.

 

This patient is suffering from systemic mycosis and is infected with Candida species.

The treatment of choice for invasive candidiasis is

  • Echinocandins (caspofungin, micafungin, anidulafungin)
    • Used as first line agents
    • They can also be used if azole resistance is present or a contraindication to amphotericin B is present - renal disorders.
  • Alternative therapy - Liposomal amphotericin B
  • If the patient is stable and the Candida spp is identified as Azole sensitive - step down therapy with Fluconazole
    • Candida krusei is resistant to azoles
    • CNS or ophthalmic involvement - Voriconazole (Better tissue penetration)

 

Candida albicans, Candida glabrata, and Candida dubliniensis are sensitive and respond well to azoles (Options A,B, and C).

questions.text: A 32-year-old HIV-positive male presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of worsening shortness of breath, dry cough, and fever. He reports significant weight loss over the past month and has a CD4 count of 150 cells/mm³. HRCT Thorax shows ground-glass opacities. A bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is performed, and a histological examination shows organisms with a characteristic appearance, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pneumocystis Carinii pneumonia (PCP)

Explanation:

Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia (PCP), now known as Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, is a common opportunistic infection in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with HIV/AIDS.

Pneumocystis jirovecii

Morphology
  1. Trophozoite - thin-walled, irregularly shaped, 1-5 µm in size
  2. Precyst - an intermediate stage of the sexual phase, 5-8 µm in size
  3. Cyst - thick-walled, spherical, containing up to 8 intracystic bodies and up to 8 µm in size

Risk factors
  • HIV: CD4 < 200
  • Primary immunodeficiency states
  • Transplant recipients
  • Hematological malignancies

Clinical features

transmitted by respiratory droplets and is asymptomatic in immunocompetent individuals. In immunocompromised patients, life-threatening pneumonia develops.

PCP - Pneumocystis Carinii pneumonia

  • Dyspnoea
  • Dry cough
  • Fever
  • Weight loss
  • B/L interstitial pneumonia

Diagnosis
  • GMS / Giemsa stain- mc used
  • Giemsa, toluidine blue, methenamine silver, and calcofluor white stains can demonstrate trophozoites - cyst wall is black with a methenamine silver stain.

Crushed Ping Pong ball (also called Helmet/Hat or Cup and Saucer appearance).

 

  • The β-d-glucan test has proven to be quite useful for rapid diagnosis of Pneumocystis pneumonia with a high degree of sensitivity and specificity.

Treatment
  • The cornerstone for both prevention and treatment is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
 
  • Alternative therapies have been used in AIDS patients; they include pentamidine, trimethoprim-dapsone, clindamycin-primaquine, atovaquone, and trimetrexate.

 

Bacterial pneumonia (Option A): Is caused by various bacteria (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus) and typically presents with symptoms such as productive cough, high fever, and localized crackles on auscultation. Chest X-rays often show lobar consolidation rather than the diffuse ground-glass opacities characteristic of PCP.

 

Tuberculosis (TB) (Option B): Is a chronic infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It usually presents with a persistent cough, night sweats, weight loss, and hemoptysis.

 

Fungal pneumonia (Option D): Can be caused by various fungi, such as Histoplasma, Coccidioides, or Cryptococcus. These infections typically present differently from PCP, often with more localized symptoms and findings on imaging

Explanation:

The β-1,3-D-glucan test is not specific for Aspergillus; it can also be positive in infections caused by other fungi, such as Candida.

 

Clinical studies have demonstrated the utility of this assay for diagnosing invasive fungal infections.

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic male presents to the emergency department with facial swelling, nasal discharge, and fever. He has a history of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. On examination, there is necrosis of the nasal turbinates and blackish discharge. A CT scan of the sinuses reveals extensive necrosis. A tissue biopsy shows non-septate, wide-angle hyphae similar to the image given below. What is the most common causative organism of the above condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Rhizopus Arrhizus

Explanation:

Rhizopus Arrhizus, also known as R. oryzae, is the most common causative organism of mucormycosis, especially in diabetic patients. It features non-septate hyphae that branch at right angles.

Mucormycosis

It is an invasive disease caused by zygomycetes (phycomycetes) - Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia. Rhizopus Arrhizus is the most common pathogen

 

Pathogenesis

Begins in the respiratory tract or nasal cavity, where spores germinate and form mycelia → invade adjacent tissues, leading to local destruction.

 

Fungi invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis and infarction in affected areas, which contributes to its high mortality rate (Angio-invasiveness)

 

Common Sites

  • Rhinocerebral Form: Involves the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit; frequently seen in diabetic patients.
 
  • Pulmonary Infections: When the lungs are the primary site, the fungi can invade lung arteries, leading to serious complications.
 
  • Others: Cutaneous mucormycosis, GI mucormycosis, Disseminated mucormycosis

Clinical Features
  • Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis:
    • Facial swelling, nasal discharge (often black), fever, and mucosal necrosis.
    • Rapid progression can lead to severe complications, including visual loss and neurological symptoms.
  • Pulmonary Zygomycosis:
    • Symptoms may include cough, fever, and hemoptysis

Diagnosis

Histological Examination:

Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying broad, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae.

 

Culture:

  • After incubation for 3-4 days on Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, the colonies are grey-white with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.
  • Under the microscope, nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores are seen.)

a. 

 

b. 

a.Sabouraud's dextrose agar (SDA) medium showing Rhizopus growth

b.Microscopy of LPCB stained preparation demonstrating morphology of Rhizopus spp. (non-septate hyphae, sporangiophore, sporangium and spores)

Treatment:
  • Intravenous amphotericin B combined, where appropriate, with surgical drainage is the recommended treatment.
  • Medical control of diabetes is required.

Aspergillus species (Option A & B), typically produce septate hyphae that branch at acute angles. The presence of non-septate, wide-angle hyphae in this case makes Aspergillus an unlikely causative organism.

Features

Absidia species (Option C) : can cause mucormycosis. It typically has a similar morphology, with non-septate hyphae, but is less common than Rhizopus.

questions.text: In which of the following infections can galactomannan in serum be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Aspergillus infection

 

Explanation:

Galactomannan is primarily associated with Aspergillus infections, particularly invasive aspergillosis.

  • Galactomannan is a component of the Aspergillus cell wall
  • Detection of Galactomannan in serum or bronchoalveolar lavage fluid is a marker for the diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis in adults and children, in hematopoietic stem cell transplant recipients or in patients with hematologic malignancies.

 

Galactomannan Test: Detects galactomannan, a carbohydrate antigen specific to Aspergillus species.

  • Positive for: Aspergillus species
  • False-negative for: Most fungi except Aspergillus; not reliable for Candida, Pneumocystis jirovecii, or Mucorales.


 

Candidiasis (Option A): Candidiasis is caused by Candida species, such as Candida albicans. While Candida infections can be serious, they do not typically produce galactomannan. Diagnosis is usually made through culture.

 

Cryptococcosis (Option C): Cryptococcosis is caused by Cryptococcus neoformans.The diagnosis usually involves detecting cryptococcal antigen (CrAg) in serum or cerebrospinal fluid or by Indian ink stain microscopy of CSF, not by detection of serum galactomannan.

 

Mucormycosis (Option D): It does not produce galactomannan. Diagnosis is typically through culture or histopathological examination, rather than serological tests for galactomannan.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of COPD presents to the emergency department with 1-week history of fever, cough, and worsening shortness of breath. Colonies exhibiting a yellow-green color and a velvety texture were isolated from the culture. He is immunocompromised due to long-term corticosteroid therapy. The attending physician wants to initiate antifungal therapy. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Voriconazole

Explanation: 

In this case, the patient is diagnosed with disseminated aspergillosis, presenting with pneumonia. Given his immunocompromised status from long-term corticosteroid treatment, the risk of disseminated fungal infection is high.

Voriconazole is the preferred first-line treatment for disseminated aspergillosis

It is specifically effective in patients with compromised immune systems, making it suitable for this patient's condition, given his history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and long-term corticosteroid therapy.

Aspergillosis

Type

Pathology

Features

1. ABPA (allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis)

Inhaled spores provoke hypersensitivity reaction:

  • Type 1: asthma
  • Type 3: extrinsic alveolitis
  • Combined type 1 and type 3
 

Chest X-ray showing: left-sided perihilar opacity (blue arrow) along with non-homogeneous infiltrates (transient pulmonary infiltrates indicated by red arrows) in all zones of both lung fields

2. Aspergilloma

Fungal ball grows within and is restricted to an existing lung cavity, for example, due to old tuberculosis infection or bronchiectasis.
 

CT of a simple aspergilloma of the right lung

3. Invasive aspergillosis

Fungus first causes pneumonia and later disseminates to involve other organs, for example, the brain, kidney or heart.

 

Patients who develop this disease are usually immunocompromised or debilitated due to prolonged treatment with antibiotics, steroids and cytotoxic drugs.
 

Invasive Aspergillus infection showing a nodule with a halo sign at the periphery (arrows).

4. Superficial

Superficial infections of the external ear ( otomycosis), the eye (mycotic keratitis) and the nasal sinuses.

  

Otomycosis of the External Canal (Wet newspaper appearance)

A. Mycotic keratitis B.Under cobalt blue filter after instillation of fluorescein dye.

Diagnosis

Culture

Colonies have a velvety to powdery surface and are characteristically coloured: A.fumigatus - dark green, A.niger - black, A.flavus - yellow-green, A.terreus - beige coloured colonies.

 

 

Aspergillus fumigatus

 

Aspergillus niger

 

Aspergillus flavus 

 

Aspergillus terreus

Histopathology

Stain used - Lactophenol cotton blue

It demonstrates septate hyphae and acute angled (<45°) / Dichotomous branching.

Others

Detection of galactomannan

Tissue sections: biopsy (stained with GMS/PAS)

Treatment

Medical

Drug of choice: Voriconazole (Option A)

2nd line drugs: Itraconazole (Option C), Posaconazole

Other drugs: Amphotericin B (Option B) / Liposomal amphotericin B

Surgical resection (Option D)

May be indicated for localized fungal infections, such as aspergillomas or when there are complications such as abscess formation.

questions.text: A 12-year-old female patient with a history of cystic fibrosis presents to the clinic with complaints of worsening facial pain, nasal congestion, and a brownish purulent nasal discharge for the past 2 weeks. A nasal endoscopy is performed, and a sample of the discharge is sent for microscopy and culture. If the patient is diagnosed with rhinosinusitis of fungal etiology, which of the following pathogens is most likely to be responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Aspergillus

Explanation:

Based on the patient's clinical presentation and her history of cystic fibrosis, she is most likely suffering from aspergillus rhinosinusitis.

Aspergillus rhinosinusitis

Risk factor

  • Asthma No mi
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Immunocompromised state

Clinical features

  • Facial pain or pressure, particularly in the sinus areas (maxillary or frontal sinuses), gradual onset
  • Nasal congestion and obstruction.
  • Purulent nasal discharge.

Microscopy

Acute angle dichotomous branching hyphae + septate hyphae

 

Aspergillus-Acute angled branched septate hyphae

 


 

Mucor and Rhizopus (Options A, B): Members of the Zygomycetes group typically group, typically feature broad, non-septate hyphae that branch at 90 degrees or more. They cause mucormycosis, which presents rapidly and aggressively, often with black necrotic tissue and more severe systemic symptoms. It is associated with diabetes mellitus and other immunocompromised states.

 

Mucor-Ribbon-like hyphae which branch at 90°

 


 

Pneumocystis (Option C) causes pneumonia with a dry cough. It is associated with HIV/AIDS (CD4+ <200 cells/μL). On microscopy, it appears like a crushed ping-pong ball (helmet/hat or cup and saucer appearance).

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about Cryptococcus are correct?

 

i. It is a mould type of fungi

ii. Polypeptide capsule provides significant protection against phagocytosis.

iii. Exposure to bird droppings can increase the likelihood of infection.

iv. Cryptococcus neoformans is the principle pathogenic species

v. Cryptococcus gattii is associated with B, C serotypes.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) iii, iv and v only

 

Explanation:

 

Cryptococcus Spp.

Cryptococcus is a true yeast. (Statement i)

Capsule

Polysaccharide capsule - helps in serotyping and protection against phagocytosis . (Statement ii)

Serotypes

A, D, AD serotypes - Cryptococcus variety neoformans (Statement iv)

B, C serotypes -Cryptococcus variety gattii (Statement v)

Virulence factors
  • Polysaccharide Capsule: The primary virulence factor. It helps the pathogen evade phagocytosis and suppresses the host’s local immune responses, enabling the organism to survive and spread.
  • Melanin Production: Cryptococcus produces melanin via the enzyme phenol oxidase, which contributes to its virulence by protecting the pathogen from oxidative stress and immune defenses.
  • Enzyme Production: The fungus secretes several enzymes, including:
  • Phospholipase: Aids in tissue invasion and damage.
  • Urease: Helps the fungus survive in the host environment by neutralizing acidic conditions, enhancing its ability to colonize and spread.

Risk of infection

Immunocompromised States:

  • HIV/AIDS, cancer, organ transplant recipients, those on immunosuppressive therapies, extremes of age are at higher risk.

Geographic Location:

  • Exposure to environments where Cryptococcus gattii is endemic, such as tropical and subtropical regions

Environmental Exposure:

  • Exposure to bird droppings or decaying wood can increase the likelihood of infection, especially with C. neoformans. (Statement iii)

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to her primary care physician with complaints of intense vaginal itching, a thick, white, curd-like vaginal discharge, and irritation. Per vaginal examination reveals the following finding. The vaginal pH is found to be acidic (approximately 4.5). What is the most appropriate management for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Topical nystatin

Explanation:

Given the patient’s symptoms, risk factors, and the acidic vaginal pH, the presentation is consistent with vaginal candidiasis and the treatment of choice is Topical nystatin

Vaginal candidiasis

Risk factors

  • Old age
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Corticosteroid use
  • Pregnancy
  • Immunocompromised states - HIV
  • Low neutrophil count

Presentation

Intense vaginal itching and irritation

Splash dysuria seen

Thick, white, curd-like vaginal discharge

Treatment

Topical nystatin - DOC for uncomplicated cases

 

Oral fluconazole (Option B) used for more severe or recurrent infections that do not respond to standard treatment.

Topical metronidazole (Option C): Metronidazole is an antibiotic primarily used for bacterial infections or protozoal infections( Bacterial vaginosis, Trichomoniasis) and does not treat fungal infections like vaginal candidiasis.

Topical hydrocortisone (Option D): Although hydrocortisone can help reduce inflammation and itching, it does not treat the fungal infection itself.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of poorly controlled diabetes presents with white patches on the tongue and inner cheeks. On examination, the lesions can be scraped off, revealing a red, inflamed base. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Oral candidiasis

Explanation:

The diagnosis is Oral candidiasis/ Moniliasis, indicated by the presence of white patches that can be scraped off and the patient's risk factors, including poorly controlled diabetes.

Oral candidiasis

Oral candidiasis, commonly known as thrush, is an infection caused by an overgrowth of Candida albicans, a type of yeast.

Presentation

Presence of white patches that can be scraped off, leaving behind a red inflamed base

Risk factors

  • Diabetes: Poorly controlled diabetes creates a favorable environment for Candida growth due to elevated blood sugar levels.
  • Neutropenia
  • Immunosuppression: HIV/AIDS, cancer, or immunosuppressive medications increase susceptibility.
  • Use of inhaled corticosteroids
  • Antibiotic Use: Broad-spectrum antibiotics can disrupt normal oral flora, allowing Candida to overgrow.
  • Poor Oral Hygiene: Leads to an increase in fungal colonization.
  • Dry Mouth: Conditions that lead to reduced saliva production can promote candidiasis.

Treatment
  • Antifungal medications, such as nystatin or fluconazole, along with addressing any underlying risk factors.
  • C. krusei- Resistant to azoles


 

Oral leukoplakia (Option A) presents as white patches that cannot be scraped off and may indicate precancerous changes.

 

Lichen planus (Option C) presents with white, lacy patches and ulcerations in the mouth. The lesions are typically painful and not easily scraped off.

 

Herpes simplex stomatitis (Option D) caused by HSV, presents as gingivostomatitis or pharyngitis, with painful vesicles on the buccal mucosa. Recurrent infections often lead to herpes labialis. Other lesions can include ulcerative stomatitis, tonsillitis, and eyelid vesicles. Many cases are asymptomatic but may predispose to secondary bacterial infections.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Cryptococcus gattii except?

choices.text: C. gattii is commonly found in Tropical and subtropical parts
It corresponds to the serotypes B and C
C. gattii inhabits around eucalyptus tree

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) It primarily affects immunocompromised individuals

 

Explanation:

Cryptococcus gattii is known for causing infections primarily in immunocompetent individuals, which distinguishes it from Cryptococcus neoformans, which mainly affects immunocompromised patients.

 

  • Commonly found in tropical and subtropical regions, particularly around eucalyptus trees (Options A and C ruled out)
  • It corresponds to the serotypes B and C (Option B ruled out)
  • C. gattii can cause severe respiratory illnesses and can disseminate to the CNS, leading to cryptococcal meningitis.
  • Diagnosis is typically made through microscopy, culture, serological tests for cryptococcal antigen, and imaging studies for lung lesions.
  • Treatment usually involves antifungal medications, such as amphotericin B and fluconazole, depending on the severity of the infection.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents to the clinic with a persistent cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain for the past month. She is currently on immunosuppressive therapy for an autoimmune condition. A chest CT reveals a solitary pulmonary nodule in the right upper lobe. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Pulmonary cryptococcosis

 

Explanation:

Pulmonary cryptococcosis is the most likely diagnosis due to the patient’s immunocompromised state and the solitary pulmonary nodule on imaging.

 

Clinical features of cryptococcosis

Respiratory system
  • Cryptococcus typically enters the body via inhalation and can cause pulmonary infection/pneumonitis - primary site of infection
  • Patients may present with cough, pleuritic chest pain, and respiratory distress.
  • Imaging shows a solitary pulmonary nodule
  • Dissemination of pulmonary infection leads to involvement of other organs

Central Nervous System

Meningitis: Characterized by severe headaches, fever, altered mental status, sensory and memory loss, cranial nerve paresis and loss of vision

It is the most serious type of cryptococcal infection

Skin

Cutaneous Cryptococcosis: Causes skin lesions, particularly in immunocompromised patients.

Associated with C.neoformans var neoformans (serotype D)

Other Organs

Liver, spleen, and bones may be involved in disseminated infections



 

Bacterial pneumonia (Option A) typically presents with acute symptoms like high fever and productive cough, and Imaging usually shows diffuse infiltrates or lobar consolidation, not a solitary nodule

 

Pulmonary tuberculosis (Option B) often involves systemic symptoms (weight loss, night sweats) and typically presents as multiple nodules or cavitary lesions on imaging

 

Lung abscess (Option D) presents with localized symptoms and is associated with bacterial infections. Imaging typically reveals a cavity filled with pus, not a solitary nodule.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male, known to be HIV positive, presents with fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, and altered mental status. A lumbar puncture is performed to analyze his cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), and following microscopic findings are observed. What stain has been used here to visualize the organism?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) India ink stain

 

Explanation:

The given scenario describes meningitis and India ink stain is used to visualize the organism in this scenario.

  • The India ink stain (A type of negative stain) is specifically used to visualize the capsule surrounding Cryptococcus neoformans in CSF samples.
  • A clear halo around the yeast cells indicates the presence of the capsule, which is an important virulence factor.
  • Urease test positive
  • Maltese cross appearance under polarising microscope

 

Diagnosis of Cryptococcosis

Microscopy

  • India ink- Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells
  • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

Culture
  • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.
  • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.
  • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci

Antigen detection tests

Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

Treatment

  • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine
  • Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.
  • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.
  • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.



 

Gram stain (Option A) is used to classify bacteria into Gram-positive or Gram-negative, and it does not visualize the capsule of Cryptococcus.

 

Acid-fast stain (Option C) is used primarily to identify Mycobacterium species, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, but it does not detect Cryptococcus. Acid-fast bacteria have mycolic acid in their cell wall, which can be stained with acid-fast / Ziehl Nielsen stain.

 

Giemsa stain (Option D) contains both acidic and basic dyes, which helps identify certain blood parasites and cellular components.

  • Eosin is an acidic dye that stains the cytosol and cytosolic granules red
  • Methylene blue stain that stains the nucleus, cytosolic RNA and basophilic granules blue
  • Azure dye stains the acidic components of the cells such as phosphate groups of DNA
